elements.content: To explore the effect of the isomeric organic ligand on the helical structure, herein, three Wells–Dawson polyoxometalates (POMs) based hybrid compounds with different helical structures by using the isomeric pyttz organic ligands, [Ag5(pyttz-I)3­(H2O)2­(HP2W18O62)]­·H2O (1), [Ag10(pyttz-II)6­(trz)2(H2O)6]­[HP2W18O62]2­·8H2O (2), and K2[Ag7(pyttz-III)4]­[P2W18O62]­·2H2O (3), were successfully isolated. Compound 1 shows a three-dimensional (3D) inorganic framework constructed by three kinds of pure inorganic helical chains and steadied by organic molecules, and so does compound 2, but the 3D framework is constructed by two types of organic–inorganic hybrid helical chains. Note that compound 3 shows a two-dimensional layer with one kind of organic–inorganic hybrid helical chain. The influences of the organic ligand on helical structures of the new compounds have been reported. In addition, the photocatalytic results of three new compounds for the photodecomposition of MB indicate Wells–Dawson POMs based hybrid compounds are one kind of good photocatalyst to some dye pollutants.

elements.content: By utilizing an isomeric organic ligand (m-, p-, o-pyttz), three Wells-Dawson polyoxometalates based compounds with different helices have been synthesized, in which the pyttz molecules play a significant role in determining the structure of compounds.

elements.content: Assembly of crystalline materials with a helix has had intense interest because of their fascinating structures and multifunctional properties in optical devices and asymmetric catalysis. An important synthesis strategy for constructing the helix is the design and utilization of V-shaped or flexible asymmetrical bridging organic ligands. However, it should be noted that inorganic anions or clusters can also participate in the construction of the helical framework. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are one class of smart inorganic candidates for constructing a helix owing to their diverse structures and abundant functions. More importantly, a large number of terminal and bridging oxygen atoms can be used to coordinate with others, which can exhibit versatile coordination geometries including V-shaped coordination. In fact, many POMs based compounds (POMCPs) with helical characteristics have been recently reported, in which POMs were used as building subunits or templates. In the research field, our groups also synthesized many POMCPs with helices by altering the types of the reactants,and the information about structures and reactants is illuminated in . From , we can find that pyttz organic ligand (Scheme S1) is advantageous to the construction of a helix and plays an important role in the final structure, because it is one kind of conjugated heterocyclic ligand with a rigid plane and abundant coordinated nitrogen atoms, which may bring a versatile coordination mode. On the other hand, as a smart inorganic ligand, the coordination of POMs can change with the nature of reactants. Both are positive and significant to the assembly of POMCPs with helix.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Assembly of crystalline materials with a helix has had intense interest because of their fascinating structures and multifunctional properties in optical devices and asymmetric catalysis. An important synthesis strategy for constructing the helix is the design and utilization of V-shaped or flexible asymmetrical bridging organic ligands. However, it should be noted that inorganic anions or clusters can also participate in the construction of the helical framework. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are one class of smart inorganic candidates for constructing a helix owing to their diverse structures and abundant functions. More importantly, a large number of terminal and bridging oxygen atoms can be used to coordinate with others, which can exhibit versatile coordination geometries including V-shaped coordination. In fact, many POMs based compounds (POMCPs) with helical characteristics have been recently reported, in which POMs were used as building subunits or templates. In the research field, our groups also synthesized many POMCPs with helices by altering the types of the reactants,and the information about structures and reactants is illuminated in . From , we can find that pyttz organic ligand (Scheme S1) is advantageous to the construction of a helix and plays an important role in the final structure, because it is one kind of conjugated heterocyclic ligand with a rigid plane and abundant coordinated nitrogen atoms, which may bring a versatile coordination mode. On the other hand, as a smart inorganic ligand, the coordination of POMs can change with the nature of reactants. Both are positive and significant to the assembly of POMCPs with helix.

During the assembly, we also find that the reported POMCPs with helix are mostly based on Keggin POMs, and other types, such as Wells-Dawson, Anderson, and Lindqvist and so on, have been rarely explored to date, so assembly of POMCPs with helix based on Wells–Dawson are carried out in the work, because the lower space symmetry (Td for Keggin POMs and D3h for Wells–Dawson POMs) and more coordination oxygen atoms (24 for Keggin POMs and 54 for Wells–Dawson POMs) can produce more flexible V-shaped coordination modes and more rich structural information. Herein, we utilized Wells–Dawson POMs, m-, p-, o-pyttz ligands and Ag ions to construct three new POMCPs with helix, [Ag5(pyttz-I)3­(H2O)2­(HP2W18O62)]­·H2O (1), [Ag10(pyttz-II)6­(trz)2­(H2O)6]­[HP2W18O62]2­·8H2O (2), and K2[Ag7(pyttz-III)4]­[P2W18O62]­·2H2O (3). Compound 1 shows a three-dimensional (3D) framework constructed by pure inorganic helical tunnels, and compound 2 also exhibits a 3D structure with organic–inorganic hybrid helical tunnels, but compound 3 exhibits a two-dimensional (2D) layer with organic–inorganic hybrid helical tunnels.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural analysis reveals that compounds 1 and 2 all exhibit a 3D framework, but compound 3 exhibits a 2D layer, in which three types of helical chains for 1, two kinds of organic-inorganic hybrid helical chains for 2, and one kind of organic-inorganic hybrid helical chain for 3. All W and Ag atoms are in the full oxidation state; then the molecular formulas for three new compounds are [Ag5(pyttz-I)3(H2O)2(HP2W18O62)]⋅H2O (1), [Ag10(pyttz-II)6(trz)2(H2O)6][HP2W18O62]2⋅8H2O (2), and K2[Ag7(pyttz-III)4][P2W18O62]⋅2H2O (3).

elements.content: The structural unit of compound 1 is constructed by one [P2W18O62]6– polyanions (P2W18), five Ag+ ions, three pyttz-I ligands, and three water molecules (Figure S1). There are three crystallography independent pyttz-I ligands (pyttz-I-1, pyttz-I-2, pyttz-I-3) and five crystallography independent silver ions, and their structural information are illustrated in Table S1. Bond lengths are 2.584–2.649 Å for Ag–O bonds, and 2.094–2.530 Å for Ag–N bonds and 2.817–3.174 Å for Ag–Ag bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of Compound 1 

The structural unit of compound 1 is constructed by one [P2W18O62]6- polyanions (P2W18), five Ag+ ions, three pyttz-I ligands, and three water molecules (Figure S1). There are three crystallography independent pyttz-I ligands (pyttz-I-1, pyttz-I-2, pyttz-I-3) and five crystallography independent silver ions, and their structural information are illustrated in Table S1. Bond lengths are 2.584-2.649 Å for Ag-O bonds, and 2.094-2.530 Å for Ag-N bonds and 2.817-3.174 Å for Ag-Ag bonds.

elements.content: The structure of compound 1 is made up of two moieties: 0D [Ag10(pytttz-I)6] fragment and 3D POM-Ag inorganic framework with helical tunnels. First, regardless of organic ligands, P2W18 polyanions and Ag ions (Ag1, Ag2, Ag4, and Ag5) construct a 3D inorganic framework containing three types of helical chains. More specifically, P2W18 polyanions linking with Ag ions form the left-handed helical chains via the route POMs-Ag1-POMs-Ag2-POMs-Ag1-POMs-Ag2-POMs and the right-handed helical chains via another route POMs-Ag2-POMs-Ag1-POMs-Ag2- POMs-Ag1-Ag4-POM shown in . And the helical chains possess the same pitch of screw (l6.026 Å) along the b axis and are fused into a one-dimensional (1D) tunnel by POMs, Ag1 and Ag2. Then an adjacent 1D tunnels connect with each other by the POM-Ag2-POM-Ag2-POM edges obtaining the 2D layer shown in a. Finally, the 2D layers with 1D tunnel are incorporated together forming the 3D inorganic framework via sharing Ag5 atoms shown in b. Note that P2W18 polyanions linking with Ag5 ions construct another type of helical chain in the 3D structure which possess the same POM-Ag5-POM-Ag5-POM linkage route, and the same pitch of screw along the b axis (l6.026 Å) shown in c. Different from the first type of helical chains, the second are alternately arranged in the 3D framework shown in b.

elements.content: Second, without regard to the P2W18 polyanions, five independent Ag ions (Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, Ag4, Ag5) coordinate with pyttz-I ligands generating a 0D fragment. More specifically, the pyttz-I-(1 and 2) ligands and silver ions (Ag2 and Ag3) construct a binuclear subunit [Ag2(pyttz-I)2], and then subunits assemble with pyttz-I-3 and Ag1, Ag4, and Ag5 ions forming the “hand-like” units. Finally, the “hand-like” units self-assemble into a 0D fragment in the mode of “backhand buckle” shown in a. Note that 0D fragment does not participate in the construction of helical framework and only steadies the framework by sharing Ag1, Ag2, Ag4, and Ag5 ions (b,c).

elements.content: The structural unit of compound 2 is constructed by 2 P2W18 polyanions, 10 Ag ions, 6 pyttz-II and two 1,2,4-triazole (trz) molecules, and 14 water molecules (Figure S2). There are seven crystallography independent silver ions, three crystallography independent pyttz-II molecules (pyttz-II-1, pyttz-II-2, pyttz-II-3), and one crystallography independent trz molecule, and their structural information are listed in Table S1. Bond lengths are 2.011–2.837 Å for Ag–O bonds, and 1.910–2.582 Å for Ag–N bonds and 2.807–3.217 Å for Ag–Ag bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of Compound 2 

The structural unit of compound 2 is constructed by 2 P2W18 polyanions, 10 Ag ions, 6 pyttz-II and two 1,2,4-triazole (trz) molecules, and 14 water molecules (Figure S2). There are seven crystallography independent silver ions, three crystallography independent pyttz-II molecules (pyttz-II-1, pyttz-II-2, pyttz-II-3), and one crystallography independent trz molecule, and their structural information are listed in Table S1. Bond lengths are 2.011-2.837 Å for Ag-O bonds, and 1.910-2.582 Å for Ag-N bonds and 2.807-3.217 Å for Ag-Ag bonds.

elements.content: In comparison with compound 1, compound 2 also exhibits a 3D framework constructed by the helical tunnel, which is formed by Ag ion, P2W18 polyanions, and pyttz-II molecules. Similar to compound 1, the 1D tunnel can be understood from . The oxygen-rich P2W18 polyanions, Ag ions (Ag1 and Ag4) and pyttz-II-1 and pyttz-II-2 construct the helical chains with a 17.840 Å pitch of screw along the b axis, via the route POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-1-Ag4-POMs-Ag4-yttz-II-1-Ag4-POMs-Ag1-POMs for left-handed helical chains and POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-1-Ag4-POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-1-Ag4-POMs-Ag1-POMs for right-handed helical chains. Then two types of helical chains with different orientations are fused into a 1D tunnel via sharing P2W18 polyanions. Subsequently, adjacent 1D tunnels connect with each other by sharing Ag4-pyttz-Ag4 edges forming the 2D layer shown in a. Finally, the 2D layer with 1D tunnels are fused together forming the 3D organic–inorganic hybrid framework via Ag1-pyttz-Ag3 in b. Different from compound 1, without regard to the P2W18 clusters, seven independent Ag ions coordinate with pyttz-II and trz ligands generating 1D [Ag14(pyttz-II)6(trz)2] n chains shown in c. Note that there is also another type of helical chain by sharing the Ag1-pyttz-Ag3 wall of 2D helical tunnel via the route POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-POMs-Ag1-pyttz-II-3-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-POMs for left-handed spiral and POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-pyttz-II-3-Ag1-POMs for right-handed spiral, and the different helical chains possess the same pitch of screw (17.840 Å) along the b axis and are closed obtaining another type of tunnels. As a result, the 3D organic–inorganic framework with two types of tunnels is successfully isolated.

Finally, the 2D layer with 1D tunnels are fused together forming the 3D organic-inorganic hybrid framework via Ag1-pyttz-Ag3 in b. Different from compound 1, without regard to the P2W18 clusters, seven independent Ag ions coordinate with pyttz-II and trz ligands generating 1D [Ag14(pyttz-II)6(trz)2] n  chains shown in c. Note that there is also another type of helical chain by sharing the Ag1-pyttz-Ag3 wall of 2D helical tunnel via the route POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-POMs-Ag1-pyttz-II-3-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-POMs for left-handed spiral and POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-POMs-Ag4-pyttz-II-2-Ag4-pyttz-II-3-Ag1-POMs for right-handed spiral, and the different helical chains possess the same pitch of screw (17.840 Å) along the b axis and are closed obtaining another type of tunnels. As a result, the 3D organic-inorganic framework with two types of tunnels is successfully isolated.

There are seven crystallography independent Ag ions, four crystallography independent pyttz-III ligands (pyttz-III-1, pyttz-III-2, pyttz-III-3, and pyttz-III-4), and their structural information listed in Table S1. elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of Compound 3 

The structural unit of compound 3 is constructed by one P2W18 polyanions, seven silver cations, four pyttz-III molecules, two potassium cations, and two crystalline water molecules (Figure S3). There are seven crystallography independent Ag ions, four crystallography independent pyttz-III ligands (pyttz-III-1, pyttz-III-2, pyttz-III-3, and pyttz-III-4), and their structural information listed in Table S1. Bond lengths are 2.57-2.808 Å for Ag-O bonds, and 2.092-2.85 Å for Ag-N bonds and 3.153 Å for Ag-Ag bonds.

elements.content: In compound 3, all Ag ions coordinate with pyttz-III ligands generating 1D [Ag7(pyttz)4] n chains, in which Ag2, Ag5, and Ag7 graft onto POM polyanions forming 1D organic–inorganic hybrid chains (a). Furthermore, the adjacent 1D chains linking with P2W18 polyanions obtain a 2D hybrid layer with 1D helical tunnel shown in b,c. As shown in , the Ag ions (Ag5 and Ag2) with P2W18 polyanions and pyttz-III form the left-handed spiral via the route POMs-Ag2-pyttz-III-3-Ag5-POMs-Ag5-POMs and the right-handed spiral via the route POMs-Ag5-pyttz-III-3-Ag2-POMs-Ag5-POMs, which are connected with each other obtaining 1D closed tunnels.

elements.content: By utilizing the isomers of ligands, m-pyttz for 1, p-pyttz for 2, and o-pyttz for 3, three distinctive compounds with different helical tunnels were achieved and are summarized in . Unambiguously, the pyttz molecules have an important influence on the structures of the Wells–Dawson POM based compounds. Compared with compounds 1 and 2, the coordination modes of pyttz molecules (m-, p-pyttz) possess high similarity, so the pyttz and Ag ions form the similar [Ag-pyttz] n subunits in 1 and 2. More importantly, the subunits can direct the P2W18 polyanions to identify automatically and coordinate selectively with Ag ions, namely, Ag2, Ag4, Ag4, Ag2 for 1 (the twist angle of Ag–Ag–Ag is 171.6°) and Ag1, Ag4, Ag4, Ag1 for 2 (the twist angle of Ag–Ag–Ag is 108°), which affects not only the expansion of [Ag-pyttz] n subunits (0D fragment in 1, and 1D chain in 2) (Figure S4), but also the formation of different helical structure (pure inorganic helical framework in 1, and hybrid helical framework in 2) (Figure S5). More specifically, for compound 1, the diameter (12.77 Å) of Ag-pyttz-I subunits is larger than that of P2W18 polyanions (10.32 Å × 12.15 Å), which can offer enough space to hold P2W18 polyanions and enhance the coordinated opportunity of P2W18 polyanions with Ag ions. The same reason as compound K­[Ag14(m-pyttz)4­(H2O)2]­[PW12O40]2­·(OH)­·5H2O, the pure 3D inorganic framework with helical tunnels is isolated. For compound 2, the diameter of (11.8 Å) Ag-pyttz-II subunits is too small to hold more P2W18 polyanions, which reduce the coordinated opportunity of P2W18 cluster with Ag ions. For the same reason as compound [Ag3(p-Hpyttz)2]­[H2PMo12O40], the 3D framework with hybrid helical tunnels are formed.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of pyttz Ligand on Structures of Wells-Dawson POM Based Hybrid Compounds

By utilizing the isomers of ligands, m-pyttz for 1, p-pyttz for 2, and o-pyttz for 3, three distinctive compounds with different helical tunnels were achieved and are summarized in . Unambiguously, the pyttz molecules have an important influence on the structures of the Wells-Dawson POM based compounds. Compared with compounds 1 and 2, the coordination modes of pyttz molecules (m-, p-pyttz) possess high similarity, so the pyttz and Ag ions form the similar [Ag-pyttz] n  subunits in 1 and 2. More importantly, the subunits can direct the P2W18 polyanions to identify automatically and coordinate selectively with Ag ions, namely, Ag2, Ag4, Ag4, Ag2 for 1 (the twist angle of Ag-Ag-Ag is 171.6°) and Ag1, Ag4, Ag4, Ag1 for 2 (the twist angle of Ag-Ag-Ag is 108°), which affects not only the expansion of [Ag-pyttz] n  subunits (0D fragment in 1, and 1D chain in 2) (Figure S4), but also the formation of different helical structure (pure inorganic helical framework in 1, and hybrid helical framework in 2) (Figure S5). More specifically, for compound 1, the diameter (12.77 Å) of Ag-pyttz-I subunits is larger than that of P2W18 polyanions (10.32 Å × 12.15 Å), which can offer enough space to hold P2W18 polyanions and enhance the coordinated opportunity of P2W18 polyanions with Ag ions. The same reason as compound K[Ag14(m-pyttz)4(H2O)2][PW12O40]2⋅(OH)⋅5H2O, the pure 3D inorganic framework with helical tunnels is isolated. For compound 2, the diameter of (11.8 Å) Ag-pyttz-II subunits is too small to hold more P2W18 polyanions, which reduce the coordinated opportunity of P2W18 cluster with Ag ions. For the same reason as compound [Ag3(p-Hpyttz)2][H2PMo12O40], the 3D framework with hybrid helical tunnels are formed.

elements.content: Representations of the structural information about reactant and the final frameworks in compounds 1–3.
elements.clean_text: 8  Representations of the structural information about reactant and the final frameworks in compounds 1-3.

elements.content: Additionally, through the structural analysis of compound 3, we find that N atoms in two trz rings and one pyridine ring of o-pyttz ligand coordinate with Ag ions, which reduce the extended chance of the Ag-pyttz-III fragment in more directions owing to a chelating effect. As a result, the Ag-pyttz-III fragments only extend along the rigid planar direction of the ligand. Additionally, the asymmetric coordination mode of P2W18 polyanions in 3 results in a different twist angle (152.7° and 164.7°) and the shorter diameter of distance (10.5 Å), which have not enough space to accommodate P2W18 cluster. Finally, the 2D structure with a 1D hybrid helical tunnel is successfully obtained.
elements.clean_text: Additionally, through the structural analysis of compound 3, we find that N atoms in two trz rings and one pyridine ring of o-pyttz ligand coordinate with Ag ions, which reduce the extended chance of the Ag-pyttz-III fragment in more directions owing to a chelating effect. As a result, the Ag-pyttz-III fragments only extend along the rigid planar direction of the ligand. Additionally, the asymmetric coordination mode of P2W18 polyanions in 3 results in a different twist angle (152.7° and 164.7°) and the shorter diameter of distance (10.5 Å), which have not enough space to accommodate P2W18 cluster. Finally, the 2D structure with a 1D hybrid helical tunnel is successfully obtained.

elements.content: The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) for three new compounds are presented in Figure S6, and the experimental pattern is almost same as that of the simulated pattern, except for a little difference about reflection intensities, which manifests that three new compounds are the purity phase. IR spectra are presented in Figure S7. Characteristic peaks at 1091, 958, 906, and 787 cm–1 for compound 1, and 1090, 958, 905, and 783 cm–1 for 2, 1089, 956, 905, and 785 cm–1 for 3 are assigned to νas (P–O), νas (O–W), νas (W–Ob-W), and νas (W–Oc-W) vibrations. Vibration peaks in the region of 1608–1193 cm–1 are regarded as to that of pyttz molecules. And XRPD and IR of compounds 1–3 have exactly the similarity of peak position and intensity before and after photodegradation of MB (Figures S6 and S7), which confirms the stability and purity of the compounds as photocatalysts.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD Pattern, IR Spectra, and TG-DTA Analyses

The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) for three new compounds are presented in Figure S6, and the experimental pattern is almost same as that of the simulated pattern, except for a little difference about reflection intensities, which manifests that three new compounds are the purity phase. IR spectra are presented in Figure S7. Characteristic peaks at 1091, 958, 906, and 787 cm-1 for compound 1, and 1090, 958, 905, and 783 cm-1 for 2, 1089, 956, 905, and 785 cm-1 for 3 are assigned to νas (P-O), νas (O-W), νas (W-Ob-W), and νas (W-Oc-W) vibrations. Vibration peaks in the region of 1608-1193 cm-1 are regarded as to that of pyttz molecules. And XRPD and IR of compounds 1-3 have exactly the similarity of peak position and intensity before and after photodegradation of MB (Figures S6 and S7), which confirms the stability and purity of the compounds as photocatalysts.

elements.content: The thermal stability (TG-DTA) curves are shown in Figure S8. For compounds 1–3, the thermal analysis all exhibit two steps of weight loss: the first loss is 0.92% at 40–160 °C for 1, 2.21% at 40–130 °C for 2, and 0.59% at 40–100 °C for 3, which corresponds to the loss of all water (calc. 0.96% for 1, 2.20% for 2 and 0.59% for 3). And the second loss is 11.4% (calc. 11.0%) at 370–630 °C for 1, 12.3% (calc. 12.34%) at 420–610 °C for 2 and 14.1% (calc. 14.02%) at 380–600 °C for 3 arising from the decomposition of the pyttz organic molecules. The total weight loss agrees with the calculated value for compounds 1–3.

And the second loss is 11.4% (calc. 11.0%) at 370-630 °C for 1, 12.3% (calc. 12.34%) at 420-610 °C for 2 and 14.1% (calc. 14.02%) at 380-600 °C for 3 arising from the decomposition of the pyttz organic molecules. The total weight loss agrees with the calculated value for compounds 1-3.

elements.content: The diffuse reflectivity of compounds 1–3 was measured in order to determine the band gaps (Eg), which is defined as reverse extension point between energy axis and linear Kubelka–Munk absorption intensity. As shown in Figure.S9, according to the corresponding absorption intensity, Eg values of compounds 1–3 are assessed as 2.49, 1.98, and 2.18 eV, which indicates that three new compounds have semiconductor properties and can be used as potential photocatalyst.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Energy Gap

The diffuse reflectivity of compounds 1-3 was measured in order to determine the band gaps (Eg), which is defined as reverse extension point between energy axis and linear Kubelka-Munk absorption intensity. As shown in Figure.S9, according to the corresponding absorption intensity, Eg values of compounds 1-3 are assessed as 2.49, 1.98, and 2.18 eV, which indicates that three new compounds have semiconductor properties and can be used as potential photocatalyst.

elements.content: POMCPs have been proven to be an excellent kind of photocatalyst. In the work, methylene blue dye (MB) was selected for exploring the photocatalytic activities of compounds 1–3, and photocatalytic performances were tested according to the literature methods. As shown in a, the absorbance of MB solution decreased with increasing time, which indicates that MB is decomposed under the UV irradiation. After 120 min, the decomposition rate of MB solution could be up to 69.1% for 1, 73.8% for 2, 65.9% for 3, 6.6% for no compound, respectively, which indicates that compounds based on Wells–Dawson POMs have good degradation effect on MB. Further studies about the stability and reproducibility are also carried out shown in b, and the results show that compounds 1–3 do not exhibit a significant decrease after five runs in the same photocatalytic tests (69.1% for 1, 73.8% for 2, and 65.9% for 3 for the first cycles, 69.3% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 66.0% for 3 for the second cycles, 69.4% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.7% for 3 for the third cycles, 69.1% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.8% for 3 for the fourth cycles, 69.2% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.4% for 3 for the fifth cycles), which manifest that the compounds 1–3 as photocatalysts are very stable and possess good reproducibility.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalysis Properties

POMCPs have been proven to be an excellent kind of photocatalyst. In the work, methylene blue dye (MB) was selected for exploring the photocatalytic activities of compounds 1-3, and photocatalytic performances were tested according to the literature methods. As shown in a, the absorbance of MB solution decreased with increasing time, which indicates that MB is decomposed under the UV irradiation. After 120 min, the decomposition rate of MB solution could be up to 69.1% for 1, 73.8% for 2, 65.9% for 3, 6.6% for no compound, respectively, which indicates that compounds based on Wells-Dawson POMs have good degradation effect on MB. Further studies about the stability and reproducibility are also carried out shown in b, and the results show that compounds 1-3 do not exhibit a significant decrease after five runs in the same photocatalytic tests (69.1% for 1, 73.8% for 2, and 65.9% for 3 for the first cycles, 69.3% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 66.0% for 3 for the second cycles, 69.4% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.7% for 3 for the third cycles, 69.1% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.8% for 3 for the fourth cycles, 69.2% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.4% for 3 for the fifth cycles), which manifest that the compounds 1-3 as photocatalysts are very stable and possess good reproducibility.

(b) Recycling experiments using compounds for the photocatalytic degradation of MB solution.

elements.content: By utilizing isomeric organic ligand, m-pyttz, p-pyttz, and o-pyttz, three new hybrid compounds based on Wells–Dawson POMs have been synthesized and characterized, and their versatile helical structures indicate that the isomeric pyttz organic ligands have a significant effect on the framework of POMCPs. The results are veru consistent with that of POMCPs based Keggin POMs by using isomeric pyttz organic ligands, and the successful isolation of three new compounds will help to understand the assembly of the POMCP system with helical structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By utilizing isomeric organic ligand, m-pyttz, p-pyttz, and o-pyttz, three new hybrid compounds based on Wells-Dawson POMs have been synthesized and characterized, and their versatile helical structures indicate that the isomeric pyttz organic ligands have a significant effect on the framework of POMCPs. The results are veru consistent with that of POMCPs based Keggin POMs by using isomeric pyttz organic ligands, and the successful isolation of three new compounds will help to understand the assembly of the POMCP system with helical structures.

elements.content: All experimental materials were commercially obtained and were not purified before used. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were conducted on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The XRPD were recorded through a Rigaku D/MAX 2500 V diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation. IR spectra were collected on an Alpha Centaurt FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The thermal stability analyses were detected on a PerkinElmer TGA7 instrument under the protection of flowing N2. The diffuse reflectance spectra were scanned on a T9 spectrometer, and the UV–vis spectra were recorded on a 756 CRT spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

All experimental materials were commercially obtained and were not purified before used. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were conducted on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The XRPD were recorded through a Rigaku D/MAX 2500 V diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation. IR spectra were collected on an Alpha Centaurt FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The thermal stability analyses were detected on a PerkinElmer TGA7 instrument under the protection of flowing N2. The diffuse reflectance spectra were scanned on a T9 spectrometer, and the UV-vis spectra were recorded on a 756 CRT spectrophotometer.

elements.content: The reaction of K6P2W18O62 (300 mg), AgNO3 (200 mg), pyttz-I (40 mg), and 12 mL of distilled H2O was performed by stirring for 2 h with room temperature and adjusting the pH value to 1.5 or so. Then the mixture was heated to 170 °C in Teflon-lined reactor for 3 days, while upon cooling yielded yellow block crystal of 1 in 38% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for C27H19N21Ag5P2W18O65 (5588.03): C 5.80, H 0.34, N 5.26%; Found C 5.73, H 0.36, N 5.30%.

elements.content: Crystallographic data for 1–3 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer using monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å). The direct method and full matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL package were used to solve and refine the structure of new compounds. All the atoms were refined anisotropically except for all H atoms, C23, N6, C5, O4, O14, and O44 for 1 and O49 and O62 for 2 and C6, C7, and C31 for 3. Crystallographic data for 1–3 are given in . CCDC reference numbers are 1440339 for 1, 1440340 for 2, and 1440578 for 3.

X-ray Crystallographic Measurements

Crystallographic data for 1-3 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer using monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å). The direct method and full matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL package were used to solve and refine the structure of new compounds. All the atoms were refined anisotropically except for all H atoms, C23, N6, C5, O4, O14, and O44 for 1 and O49 and O62 for 2 and C6, C7, and C31 for 3. Crystallographic data for 1-3 are given in . CCDC reference numbers are 1440339 for 1, 1440340 for 2, and 1440578 for 3.

The reaction of K6P2W18O62 (300 mg), AgNO3 (200 mg), pyttz-I (40 mg), and 12 mL of distilled H2O was performed by stirring for 2 h with room temperature and adjusting the pH value to 1.5 or so. Then the mixture was heated to 170 °C in Teflon-lined reactor for 3 days, while upon cooling yielded yellow block crystal of 1 in 38% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for C27H19N21Ag5P2W18O65 (5588.03): C 5.80, H 0.34, N 5.26%; Found C 5.73, H 0.36, N 5.30%.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>10</sub>(pyttz-II)<sub>6(</sub>trz)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]­[HP<sub>2</sub>W<sub>18</sub>O<sub>62</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·8H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1, except that pyttz-II replaced pyttz-I. Yellow block crystal of 2 was obtained in 30% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for C29H15N24Ag5P2W18O69 (5714.05): C 6.09, H 0.26, N 5.88%; Found C 6.10, H 0.24, N 5.91%.

Synthesis of K<sub>2</sub>[Ag<sub>7</sub>(pyttz-III)<sub>4</sub>]­[P<sub>2</sub>W<sub>18</sub>O<sub>62</sub>]­·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

The preparation of 3 was similar to that of 1, except that pyttz-III replaced pyttz-I. Yellow block crystal of 3 was isolated in 42% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for K2C36H24N28Ag7P2W18O64 (6077.16): C 7.11, H 0.39, N 6.45%; Found C 7.10, H 0.41, N 6.45%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ag5(pyttz-I)3(H2O)2HP2W18O62)]⋅H2O (1)

The reaction of K6P2W18O62 (300 mg), AgNO3 (200 mg), pyttz-I (40 mg), and 12 mL of distilled H2O was performed by stirring for 2 h with room temperature and adjusting the pH value to 1.5 or so. Then the mixture was heated to 170 °C in Teflon-lined reactor for 3 days, while upon cooling yielded yellow block crystal of 1 in 38% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for C27H19N21Ag5P2W18O65 (5588.03): C 5.80, H 0.34, N 5.26%; Found C 5.73, H 0.36, N 5.30%.

Synthesis of [Ag10(pyttz-II)6(trz)2(H2O)6][HP2W18O62]2⋅8H2O (2)

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1, except that pyttz-II replaced pyttz-I. Yellow block crystal of 2 was obtained in 30% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for C29H15N24Ag5P2W18O69 (5714.05): C 6.09, H 0.26, N 5.88%; Found C 6.10, H 0.24, N 5.91%.

Synthesis of K2[Ag7(pyttz-III)4][P2W18O62]⋅2H2O (3)

The preparation of 3 was similar to that of 1, except that pyttz-III replaced pyttz-I. Yellow block crystal of 3 was isolated in 42% yield based on Ag. Anal. Calcd for K2C36H24N28Ag7P2W18O64 (6077.16): C 7.11, H 0.39, N 6.45%; Found C 7.10, H 0.41, N 6.45%.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability (TG-DTA) curves are shown in Figure S8. For compounds 1–3, the thermal analysis all exhibit two steps of weight loss: the first loss is 0.92% at 40–160 °C for 1, 2.21% at 40–130 °C for 2, and 0.59% at 40–100 °C for 3, which corresponds to the loss of all water (calc. 0.96% for 1, 2.20% for 2 and 0.59% for 3). And the second loss is 11.4% (calc. 11.0%) at 370–630 °C for 1, 12.3% (calc. 12.34%) at 420–610 °C for 2 and 14.1% (calc. 14.02%) at 380–600 °C for 3 arising from the decomposition of the pyttz organic molecules. The total weight loss agrees with the calculated value for compounds 1–3.

Optical Energy Gap

The diffuse reflectivity of compounds 1–3 was measured in order to determine the band gaps (Eg), which is defined as reverse extension point between energy axis and linear Kubelka–Munk absorption intensity. As shown in Figure.S9, according to the corresponding absorption intensity, Eg values of compounds 1–3 are assessed as 2.49, 1.98, and 2.18 eV, which indicates that three new compounds have semiconductor properties and can be used as potential photocatalyst.

Photocatalysis Properties

POMCPs have been proven to be an excellent kind of photocatalyst. In the work, methylene blue dye (MB) was selected for exploring the photocatalytic activities of compounds 1–3, and photocatalytic performances were tested according to the literature methods. As shown in a, the absorbance of MB solution decreased with increasing time, which indicates that MB is decomposed under the UV irradiation. After 120 min, the decomposition rate of MB solution could be up to 69.1% for 1, 73.8% for 2, 65.9% for 3, 6.6% for no compound, respectively, which indicates that compounds based on Wells–Dawson POMs have good degradation effect on MB. Further studies about the stability and reproducibility are also carried out shown in b, and the results show that compounds 1–3 do not exhibit a significant decrease after five runs in the same photocatalytic tests (69.1% for 1, 73.8% for 2, and 65.9% for 3 for the first cycles, 69.3% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 66.0% for 3 for the second cycles, 69.4% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.7% for 3 for the third cycles, 69.1% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.8% for 3 for the fourth cycles, 69.2% for 1, 73.7% for 2, and 65.4% for 3 for the fifth cycles), which manifest that the compounds 1–3 as photocatalysts are very stable and possess good reproducibility.
